player.seasonOutlook: A popular candidate for the No. 1 overall pick, Acuna's case is rooted in his elite combination of power and speed, as well as his ahead-of-his-prime 23 years of age. His 55 home runs and 45 stolen bases since the beginning of 2019 both ranked among the top eight in baseball, and in 2020, he became the first player in history to manage at least 75 home runs and 50 stolen bases through his first 300 career games. Still, his contact skills are lacking, as his 27.0% strikeout rate from 2019-20 was noticeably worse than the major league average, and that helps explain how Acuna batted just .274 during that time and finished exactly 23 ranking spots worse in total fantasy points than on the Player Rater in each of those two seasons. Spending the first pick on him in a dynasty or keeper league is a no-brainer, considering his still-advancing skill set, and in a 2021 rotisserie league it's a reasonable calculation, but he's more of a ?top-10 candidate? in points leagues that draft fresh annually.

For years now, Castellanos' underlying metrics have the look of a borderline MVP candidate. He gets good lift on the ball and he makes extremely hard contact, his career-best 46.7% hard hit rate in 2020 in the 83th percentile and his Statcast Barrel rate in at worst the 92nd�percentile in each of the past four seasons. Castellanos seemed on track for award votes in his first few weeks of 2020, hitting nine home runs with a .272 batting average and 1.043 OPS in his first 22 games, but he cooled thereafter, hitting only .185/.235/.370 in the month of September. It was yet another of those hard-luck final stat lines for the veteran outfielder, and while his pattern of falling short of expectations might concern prospective fantasy managers, they do help make him a relative value, especially in points-based leagues, where his skill set is a little more attractive. Castellanos is a bona fide 30-homer candidate without one yet on his r�sum�, with Great American Ball Park's cozy confines helping his cause, and he should be drafted with confidence within the top 75 overall in any format.

Anderson's batting average has been far north of .300 the past two seasons. Expecting regression seems like an easy call considering he hardly ever walks and sports an average exit velocity in the lower-third percentile but while Anderson's average is likely to drop, the landing could be softer than many expect. Parsing his exit velocity into components, he hits line drives and flyballs at an above-average clip. It's a below-normal groundball velocity lowering the overall average. The elevated exit velocity on lofted balls leads to more hits while Anderson's speed keeps his groundball BABIP above the norm, rendering him a legit .300 hitter. Add in his high exit velocity on fly balls which helps power and an 80% career stolen base success rate, and Anderson heads up the second tier at a loaded position.

Quietly, Nola has become one of the game's most consistent, durable starters. His most recent injured-list stint came in May 2017, and since his activation, he's the major-league leader in starts (103) and innings pitched (638). Nola also has a 3.23 ERA and 3.41 FIP in the past four seasons combined, never wavering by more than two-thirds of a run in either in any individual year, which signals a high degree of likelihood that he'll deliver on a top-10 fantasy starting pitching stat line. He even boosted his strikeout rate to a personal-best 33.2% last season, and while the small-sample caveat is apt, he had the underlying metrics in support of it being close to his new standard. Nola's upper-end projection probably isn't good enough to bring in first-place Cy Young votes, but the volume he offers can be plenty handy in fantasy. He's a fine pick to lead your staff.

Perhaps Steve Cohen's arrival as owner of the Mets might pay the biggest dividends for deGrom: The right-hander's 2.10 ERA since the beginning of 2018 is the majors' best qualified mark, two-tenths of a run better than the next-best pitcher's, yet he has a mere 25 wins to show for it, or 11 fewer than Marco Gonzales, whose ERA is a run and three-quarters higher during that same time span. More run support, and a better defense behind him, could turn deGrom into the kind of statistical star who runs away with the honor of No. 1 pitcher in fantasy baseball, and he was awfully close to that in the first place. He saw a near-2-mph uptick in his average fastball velocity while posting a career-best 38.8% strikeout rate in 2020, so there's no reason to believe anything's going to change for the worse in 2021.

Lux is a tough player to project for fantasy purposes because his talents are being drowned out by a deep Dodger roster. Lux would be an Opening Day player for just about any other team in baseball, but could be a bench player if not sent to Triple-A for everyday at-bats early on, unless the DH returns to the NL this year. The limited playing time over the past two seasons at the big-league level have been disappointing, particularly last season when he also struggled in the field with throws. The only reason Lux would go back to the minors in 2021 would be for regular playing time, but he has zero left to prove there offensively. The uncertainty near draft time could help him come much cheaper than what his true talent level is capable of producing should an everyday spot open up.

Pressed into big-league rotation duty in the midst of a pandemic and at the age of 22, Anderson performed admirably in six regular season and four postseason starts, to a level that the Braves were so confident in his ability that they had him start their winner-take-all Game 7 of the National League Championship Series. His changeup was excellent, limiting hitters to a .104 batting average, he whiffed nearly 30% of the hitters he faced, he generated a ground ball more than 50% of the time and he began his postseason with 18 2/3 shutout frames over parts of four starts. Anderson's success on the national stage might've inflated his fantasy draft stock, but the aforementioned traits offer plenty to like, and plenty that elevates his statistical floor, even should he be subject to adjustments in his second trip through the league. He has the skills to be a top-40 fantasy starter and might cost you less than that, and be aware that he's a building-block type for dynasty or keeper leagues.

Widely regarded the best player in baseball, Trout is no longer a slam dunk for the same honor in fantasy baseball. He placed outside the top 25 on the Player Rater while posting the worst full-season batting average (.281) and second-worst contact rate (71.9%) of his career in 2020, and he has missed 105 Angels games (most due to injuries) since the beginning of 2017. Still, that Trout's No. 27 Player Rater finish represented his lowest in any of his nine full big-league seasons speaks volumes about his Hall of Fame caliber skill set. Just since the beginning of 2018, his 101 home runs lead the majors, 252 runs scored rank sixth, .298 batting average and 229 RBI each rank 14th and 36 stolen bases rank 21st. It's the latter category that sparks genuine worry, as Trout attempted only two steals in 53 games in 2020, and as a 29-year-old, that's a skill unlikely to significantly rebound. His power metrics look as strong as ever, and with good luck in the health department that he should remain one of the most valuable commodities in fantasy. But with that No. 1 overall pick, it's probably wiser to go with someone younger or who steals more bases.

Few pitchers in history can claim as good a start to a big-league career as Gallen's. He has made 27 starts, and in 25 of those, he allowed three runs or fewer, with his 2.78 ERA since his debut the sixth-best mark among qualifiers. That statistical prowess might make Gallen a popular breakthrough pick, but strangely, he showed only minimal growth in 2020, not to mention his underlying metrics hinted he was pitching over his head. Heed his 3.64 FIP, which presents one of the larger ERA-FIP differentials, and hope that he can bring his 9.8% walk rate in the bigs down closer to the 6.4% rate he had during his minor league career. Control might be the key to his moving higher into the top 20 fantasy starters, though he's still well worth drafting as a back-end member of that tier.

How extraordinary is Cole's talent? Despite a six-start stretch in the middle of last season, during which he had a 4.19 ERA, allowed 10 home runs and won only once, he still managed to right his season to the point that he finished among the top five starting pitchers as well as top-20 overall on both the Player Rater and in fantasy points scored. In fact, that made him one of four players, and the only pitcher, to finish top-20 overall on the Player Rater in each of the past three seasons, and along with Jacob deGrom, Cole is now the only players to finish top-eight overall in fantasy points in each of the past three years. Pinstripes fit Cole well, with most of the complaints -- slight decline in strikeout rate, more home runs -- as easily explained away by statistical correction coming off an all-time type of 2019 campaign than any sort of skills decline. He's still as talented as any pitcher in baseball, a bona fide rotisserie first-rounder and a viable option for the No. 1 pick in points-based leagues.

It was a forgettable 2020 for the Red Sox, and their team-wide doldrums, coupled with what on the surface appeared like a return-to-earth performance by Devers, might help to make him a bargain despite his lofty status on draft boards. He got off to a miserable start, but in his final 40 games looked like a carbon copy of the 2019 model, outside of a troubling increase in his swing-and-miss rate, batting .301/.345/.552 during that time. Devers' contact quality is excellent, ranking among the very best in the league, and it's only a matter of time before he couples massive raw power potential with what was a closer-to-.300 hitting stroke. There's an easy case to make here that he's a potential top-25 overall fantasy player across all formats, and if he slides outside of that group, scoop him up immediately. Devers is also one of the best dynasty/keeper pieces you'll find.

Smith was already trending towards a breakthrough in 2019, as he had registered the best isolated power of his entire professional career (.243) while continuing to flash the elevated launch angle he first showed in 2018, but his star soared in the abbreviated 2020, as he mashed that isolated power number from the year before (.299 in 2020) and set all other sorts of personal bests. Unfortunately, opportunity was present at the time that isn't there in 2021, as the Mets had the designated hitter role available to them, affording them the luxury of getting Smith and Pete Alonso into the same lineup. Smith did play a lot of left field, but that's not considered a regular path to playing time for him, though he absolutely warrants a regular place in a big-league lineup now. With the requisite at-bats, he can deliver yet another top-100 fantasy season regardless of format, as he has added the power stroke to his game that scouts had long hoped. The lack of the DH in the NL for 2021, however, is going to make regular at-bats a challenge.

With James McCann now in New York, Grandal has the White Sox's primary catcher duties all to himself, just as he should have entering 2020. Grandal's first year for his new team was a relative disappointment, as his batting average and home run rate slipped slightly. He continued to elevate his launch angle, costing him batting average points, while striking out in a career-worst 30% of his trips to the plate. In the process, Grandal's patience-and-power approach at the plate widened his fantasy-valuation gap in rotisserie versus points-based and sabermetric leagues. Perhaps he'll rebound somewhat in the former now that his No. 1 catcher status is firmer, not to mention the young lineup around him a year more experienced, but this skill set is top-five fantasy catcher worthy nevertheless -- and locked-in as such in points leagues.

Hand was released by Miami in 2015 and has been an above-average reliever since. He has struck out 30% or more of the hitters he has faced in each of the last five seasons with K-BB% greater than 25% over the past four seasons. He has held the opposition to a sub-.200 average in four of the past five seasons with stellar ratios to boot. His 2019 was worrisome as he faded toward the end of the season, but his overall track record is quite strong. He does his dirty work leveraging his slider over 50% of the time as the pitch remains very tough on both righties and lefties, compensating for his declining fastball velocity. It speaks to the quality of his slider when he throws it as much as he does yet hitters continue to do little against the pitch. Now the clear No. 1 in Washington, Hand should keep on trucking in 2021.

He's on the fast track to be baseball's next megastar, and as the No. 3 overall finisher on the 2020 Player Rater who scored a 17th-best 200 fantasy points, he's already there in our circles. Tatis has everything we want in a foundational draft pick: Youth, as he's 22 years old; elite power, as he hit a fourth-in-the-majors 17 home runs; and elite speed, as he swiped an eighth-best 11 bases. What's more, he made huge strides with his contact, slashing his strikeout rate to 23.7%, coupling it with monstrous gains in contact quality -- he dominated the Statcast leaderboards. At his current rate of growth, Tatis has one remaining hurdle in his path to a universal No. 1 overall fantasy pick: Volume, as he has never amassed more than 575 plate appearances in any of five professional seasons, has two injured-list stints at the big-league level totaling 85 days missed, and  missed the final six weeks of the 2018 minor-league season with a fractured thumb. But if you firmly believe he can stay healthy over a 162-game schedule -- it'd be his first -- he's well worth the lofty investment.

May enjoyed a successful follow-up -- and technically rookie-eligible -- 2020 to his 2019 debut campaign, earning himself a spot among the top 40 pitchers in fantasy baseball. Despite this, the Dodgers regarded him more of a swingman type late in the regular season and throughout the postseason, perhaps because they saw what we have: He's more of a pitch-to-contact groundballer than a pitcher with overpowering stuff, so you need to pick and choose his spots at this career stage. May's sinker was largely behind his 54.6% ground-ball rate, and he did make enough advances with his curveball that he could be due a big step forward in 2021. Until he can perfect an offering to dominate left-handed hitters, who have slashed .278/.357/.457 against him in the majors thus far, he's not going to become the fantasy ace many expect in the future. This looks like a pitcher who's probably one big adjustment away, and while it could come in 2021, without evidence of it on the horizon, it's probably best to draft him right around his finishing point on the Player Rater.

Bundy came with a fair amount of hype last offseason after finally leaving his hitter-friendly home in Baltimore, and he wound up delivering. In 11 starts, he produced a long list of career bests, including ERA (3.29), WHIP (1.04), K% (27.0) and BB% (6.4). After allowing 1.7 HR/9 as an Oriole, he gave up just 0.7 HR/9 as an Angel. While the change in home park certainly played a role in his homer suppression, the rest of his stat line indicates that he paired that with a legitimate improvement in talent level. Bundy was the fourth overall pick way back in 2011, so him pitching at this new level didn't come out of nowhere. Whether or not he can keep it up over a 162-game season remains to be seen, but his 2020 numbers look real.

The Franimal is one of those guys who is fun to have on your team, despite his flaws. He's a massive specimen, yet still has not turned 26 so there may be more size to add to his frame. His exit velocity over the past two seasons is among the best in baseball, but it is those events between the rockets which limit his fantasy upside. Reyes has struck out in 28.4 % of his career plate appearances now over the past three seasons. On the plus side, the rate has been right at 28% each of the past three seasons, but the lack of improvement on strikeouts is concerning. Despite the whiffs, he has been able to hit .275 or better in two of his three seasons. He will miss Francisco Lindor's presence in the lineup, but expect another big year of run production hitting cleanup in Cleveland.

Ozuna spent the first seven years of his career playing half his games in Marlins Park and Busch Stadium, two of the least power-friendly venues in the league, but he still managed to post a respectable .183 ISO and .455 slugging percentage. In 2020, Ozuna played in his first hitter’s park and responded with a powerful .298 ISO and .636 SLG. The improvement wasn’t all playing in Truist Park as Ozuna’s Statcast batted-ball metrics all increased, though there is also evidence he enjoyed some good fortune. While Ozuna will be hard-pressed to repeat last season’s 96th percentile average exit velocity and 97th percentile hard-hit rate, he’s been in the upper 10th percentile for his career. Ozuna doesn’t run, but a return to Atlanta in free agency only strengthens Ozuna's case as a top-50 pick. His walk rate has improved to where he’s even better in points leagues than standard rotisserie.

Nobody expected Ryu to replicate his second-place Cy Young finish from 2019 in his age-33 season last year, but he came pretty darn close, finishing third in the voting on the back of a 2.69 ERA. His walk rate in his first year with the Blue Jays may have nearly doubled from 3.3% to 6.2%, but that came with a jump in strikeout rate from 22.5% to 26.2%. He also produced a career-best 51.1% groundball rate. The lefty did lose a tick on his fastball, which came in at 89.6 mph on average, but he adjusted by using it just 34.7% of the time, increasing his cutter usage to compensate. Ryu will be 34 by Opening Day, and he's near the lower limit of velocity for an elite pitcher, but he's been strong all-around and healthy for several seasons now.

Iglesias endured a rocky 2019 and made it clear to reporters that he was not thrilled with his usage as more than a conventional closer. That public criticism of his manager put the writing on the wall, and while Iglesias put together a bounce-back 2020 campaign, the Reds ultimately parted ways in December, trading Iglesias to the Angels. Iglesias continued to pump his fastball in at a hair over 96 mph on average in 2020 and his slider and changeup remained effective, fueling the best swinging-strike of his career (and sixth best among qualified relievers at 18.8%). He also shaved his walk rate to a career-low 5.5%. The combination of experience, results and peripherals should give Iglesias quite a bit of leash under manager Joe Maddon, and that job security puts Iglesias firmly in the second tier of closers for 2021.

As cups of coffee go, Hayes' was a metaphorical venti-sized with three extra shots of espresso. Debuting on Sept. 1, he managed the month's second-best batting average and 14 extra-base hits, putting him on the ?buzz-worthy? list for fantasy baseball purposes entering 2021. Hayes' game is well-rounded: Strong defense, good contact, decent pop, solid speed. The problem is that his performance looks better than it was, in part because of its contrast to the rest of the shortened schedule, but also because he got a lot of good fortune on balls in play, evidenced by his bloated .450 BABIP. There's statistical correction due here, and considering opposing pitchers might be more prepared for him now, it could be harsh. Hayes has bona fide five-category rotisserie ability, and his plate approach makes him equally appealing in points-based leagues, but let's not leap to All-Star starter/MVP talk just yet -- especially since his career peak is probably closer to that of a very good regular.

The list of pitchers who have made successful returns from two Tommy John surgeries to pitch at a high level is short, but Taillon embarks upon that quest as a member of the Yankees, following his January trade from the Pirates. When we last saw him in competitive game action, he had begun to shelve his ineffective changeup for a slider, and with the adjustment left-handed hitters had much more trouble hitting him (.250/.308/.381 rates from June through the end of 2019). Taillon might have his innings kept in check after such a lengthy absence, and we'd like to see a higher strikeout rate before anointing him a top comeback candidate. Still, he's a valuable depth piece to draft if he lingers into the final rounds in a mixed or middle rounds of an AL-only league.

Segura halted a three-year decline in terms of OPS, posting a .769 rate (career: .734). In 2020, he took a different route as his plate skills reversed. While Segura was more aggressive swinging at the first pitch, he offered at the same percentage of overall pitches. Unfortunately, his contact in and out of the zone fell precipitously. The result was a career-high 20.7 K%, though his 10.6 BB% was more than double his career average. A four-degree increase in average launch angle suggests Segura altered his swing, but he did not achieve the increase in average exit velocity often piggybacking this approach. More concerning is Segura was just 2-for-4 on steal attempts despite 87th percentile sprint speed. It's unclear if this is the new baseline, so Segura is best considered a handy player to grab late, with eligibility at both second and third, but no longer at shortstop.

Armed with a new slider to complement his deceptive fastball and slow curve, Peralta pitches better than his 3.99 ERA may indicate. The righthander's 4.41 FIP and 3.23 xFIP better reflect a career best 37.6% strikeout rate, the ninth-highest mark among pitchers throwing at least 25 innings. Peralta's slider itself was his third-most effective pitch, but its presence helped make his four-seam fastball and curve better. The lack of a third offering was thought to be Peralta's undoing as a starter. While there is a chance he gets another opportunity to start, it seems his role is as the conduit to the tag team of Josh Hader and Devin Williams. Peralta throws more innings than most reliever, making him a solid option in leagues where dominant relievers are useful.
